Authors:
Christer Erseus, Ida Envall, Pierre De Wit, Lena M
Gustavsson
Title:
Molecular data reveal a tropical freshwater origin of
Naidinae (Annelida, Clitellata, Naididae)
Keywords:
Naidinae, Naididae, molecular systematics, 12S rDNA, 16S
rDNA, 18S rDNA, 28S rDNA, COI, ITS, character evolution
Abstract:
The phylogenetic relationships within Naidinae (Annelida,
Clitellata, Naididae) were investigated, using six molecular markers,
both mitochondrial (12S rDNA, 16S rDNA, the COI gene) and nuclear (18S
rDNA, 28S rDNA, the ITS region). Thirty-seven nominal species,
representing 16 of the 22 genera recognized in the subfamily, were
included, and the Nais communis/variabilis species complex was
represented by six different morphotypes. Ten other species of Naididae
were selected as outgroups. The data were analysed by Bayesian
inference. The conclusion from the estimated phylogeny is that Naidinae
originated in tropical freshwaters, and this is also supported by
morphological adaptations to environmental hypoxia in the oldest
evolutionary lineages. The phylogeny also corroborates the separate
status of the genus Pristina (Pristininae) and the Opistocystinae.
Relationships within Naidinae are largely well supported, but in some
parts unexpected. A clade containing the largely tropical genera Dero
and Branchiodrilus is sister to the rest of the subfamily, and together
with a third tropical genus, Allonais, they form a basal paraphyly.
Dero, Nais and Piguetiella are paraphyletic. Branchiodrilus, Dero,
Paranais, Chaetogaster, Nais, Stylaria, and possibly also Specaria
appear to contain cryptic species. Morphological characters are to a
great extent homoplastic within Naidinae, which certainly has
contributed to the overall taxonomic confusion of this subfamily.
